s.text: They are sulfide oxidizers, using the free energy yield from the oxidation of sulfide with oxygen to fix carbon dioxide with their bacterial Rubisco enzyme.
suggest a broader mutualistic interaction between the tubeworm, its endosymbiont, and benthic hydrocarbon-degrading and sulfide-producing microbes.
Seep vestimentiferans are usually thinner, have slower growth rates, and have greater longevity than their vent relatives [10].
Seep vestimentiferans are usually thinner, have slower growth rates, and have greater longevity than their vent relatives [10].
Tubeworm blood physiology, in particular the hemoglobin molecules, are tailored specifically to the needs of the symbionts.
So where does the supply of sulfide come from at seeps that enables such large aggregations to be maintained for so long?
[15] have now provided an answer to how the stability of sulfide production is maintained over such long periods and how the worms optimize sulfide uptake.

However, the zones of high hydrocarbon turnover and sulfide flux at seeps are often limited to only a few centimeters below the seafloor, depending on hydrocarbon flows and the rate of sulfate transport from the bottom water into the sediments.
